abstract.p: Letter by Arnie Huberman responds to June 1 article on computer gamers; says he got taste of what he calls predatory practice by Microsoft when it bought site, www.zone.com, and restricted access to persons using a PC running Windows or using Internet Explorer

block.p: Gamers got a foretaste of the world of Microsoft several years ago. The Internet Gaming Zone was just as David Kushner described it (''Stop Chatting and Deal, Grandpa,'' June 1): a place for people to play games like hearts, spades and chess, while maintaining an ongoing conversation at the bottom of the screen.

It allowed me, for example, to play chess with my son, even though I was in New York City and he was at Indiana University. We played in real time with real-time chat. It also let me relax with cyberfriends.

Gamers got a foretaste of the world of Microsoft several years ago. The Internet Gaming Zone was just as David Kushner described it (''Stop Chatting and Deal, Grandpa,'' June 1): a place for people to play games like hearts, spades and chess, while maintaining an ongoing conversation at the bottom of the screen.

It allowed me, for example, to play chess with my son, even though I was in New York City and he was at Indiana University. We played in real time with real-time chat. It also let me relax with cyberfriends.

Microsoft bought the site (www.zone.com) from the entrepreneurs who started it in 1995, and within a year, access to the site was allowed only if you (a) used a PC running Windows 95 and (b) used Internet Explorer. Since my son and I used Macs, we were cut off, as well as being cut off from all the online friends we had made. That, to me, was predatory.
